title-group.article-title: The Water Industry in Scotland – Is Franchising Viable?

p.mixed-citation: The White Paper Shaping the Future - The New Councils (Cmnd 2267) set out very general proposals for the restructuring of water and sewerage services in Scotland.
For example the wholesomeness of water is defined in the Water Supply (Water Quality) (Scotland) Regulations 1990.
The Act which established the 10 Regional Water Authorities in England and Wales.
For example the government has recently brought forward proposals to franchise selected British Rail services.

More technically, Mathewson and Winter (1985) regard the franchise relationship as a hybrid between the price-mediated exchange associated with transaction in the market and 'centralised intrafirm employment'.
Williamson (1976) defines 'traditional natural monopoly services' as being gas, water and telecommunications.

Plasticity is defined by Alchian and Woodward (1988) as being a situation where justifiable discretionary decisions can be made by the agent. For example, employing the services of a lawyer exhibits a greater degree of plasticity than contracting for the construction of a road.
The question of economies of scale in the water industry is discussed by one of the co-authors in a University of Aberdeen discussion paper 'Water and Sewerage in Scotland: A Response' (1992).
Several water only companies have not yet converted to PLC status.
Yardstick or benchmark competition was discussed by Shleifer (1985) in his seminal Rand Journal article.
A system of comparative or yardstick competition is currently being developed and applied by the economic regulator of the English and Welsh companies, OFWAT.

The analytical framework of Lundqvist (1988), Sonnenblum et al. (1977) and Spencer (1984) attempts to provide a taxonomy of privatisation and as a consequence the level of state intervention in an economy.

Water quality is tightly controlled and defined according to several parameters in EC and national regulations. It is the responsibility of the drinking water inspectorate to carry out the technical audit of companies and to initiate action to secure or facilitate compliance with legal requirements.
